QID17 - If you would like to provide additional information regarding any of your responses to the above question, please do so here.
*Of course more data is always better, but I think I identified the most important time frames
*Could be useful to characterize the hypoxic zone of the central basin of Lake Erie

*I primarily work in inland waters that are in Great Lakes Basins, so I tailored my responses to that backdrop.  You as the researchers can determine whether they are useful or not, given that I don't usually work in the Great Lakes themselves.

*Temp and chlorophyll highest priority but other listed WQ parameters are important as well.  I‰Ûªm not a water quality person but I would rank pH low At leastbatbthe offshore / whole lake scale. I assume the AUV swarms would fly up and down through the water column to provide vertical profiles of all parameters. In terms of frequency, as often as possible (so depending on the spatial extent the AUV was programmed for daily would be great, but anything is better than nothing!
*I do not consider myself a fisheries worker, but a physical scientist dealing with the Great Lakes. My highest interest is measurements of temperature at all depths in the lakes.
It would seem stand along sensors (HOBO, YSI) would be a more appropriate and higher resolution option for collecting basic data.

*Water data is often able to be collected at relatively short intervals - with new sensors and technology - so should be collected at the shortest time interval as feasible with gear - In my opinion. I checked almost all boxes for "how often" based on this opinion.
temporal changes in those parameters are rare, often only grab samples for short times of year, high res data, at long time intervals would be most useful to the most people
*Collection of organisms or video work would be of particular interest to us.

Depending on how you plan to use an AUV swarm, temperature could be important.  We already have good surface temperature data from NOAA, so value added would be temperatures at depth once warming begins and before fall turnover.  More thought needs to be put into this aspect of your proposal.I submit that DO is an issue after June, rather than form April through October.
*I'm very new to fisheries management, so please weigh my responses accordingly.

*I am not sure how useful my or other answers will be to such a general question.  Yes all the variables can be important and can be important in all the specified habitats.  This does not really lead to priorities.  E.g., if you want to understand what might be inhibiting lake trout production you might focus on spawning habitat and year round.  If similarly for black bass then maybe only April -October.  Most of the variable will show substantial seasonal variation at time scale of less than a month and for some purposes you might want variables like temperature daily.
*Benthic invertebrate communities diversity and abundance, particularly in regard to benthic habitat type, quantity and quality ( ie degraded, pristine etc).
*Frequency of data collection depends on the questions being asked.  E.g., depth surveys could be done once per year, but DO surveys may be done hourly for 24 hrs once a month.
*Timing of collection depends on season- I don't think weekly collections are necessary in the winter - but during bloom season they are needed- monthly in the winter is reasonable.

*DO profiles are useful but measurements at the sediment water interface is very important and just immediately above the sediment water interface (like maybe 18 inches up. This needs measuring over a variety of substrates, silt, sand, rock.
*Any of these potential basic measurements could be useful, but I'm not certain that the scale  of a swarm of AOV's would provide data useful to me.

*Researchers at the University of Minnesota-Duluth already have an autonomous glider that collects water quality data.  Being a fisheries manager, I am more interested in fish biomass estimates (primarily Cisco).

QID20 - 7. If you chose mapping of habitat characteristics please more specifically explain your answer here.
7. If you chose mapping of habitat characteristics please more specifically explain your answer here.

Depending on the size of these AUV's, they may be able to get into shallower water than our research vessels and collect data that we normally cannot collect.Mapping of habitat likely can happen anytime, unless it is in shallow areas with vegetation growth.
Bottom substrate, extent & type of submerged aquatic vegetation, etc.
Mapping of characteristics would include:DepthWidth (wetted and bankfull)DischargeLarge woody debrisSediment
Amount of vegetation; amount of woody debris; substrate type.

Better understanding of the distribution of suitable brook trout spawning habitat in Great Lakes tributaries. Mapping of habitat characteristics at known spawning sites would increase our understanding of habitat preferences by certain species of fish.Determination of species presence (brook trout, species at risk) in Great Lakes tributaries that are currently unknown in order to protect important spawning habitat features.Sonar detection of groupings of fish - not sure of the resolution for this feature, but identifying when fish are staging before moving up Great Lakes tributaries to spawn will assist with protection of spawning habitats.
Potential lake trout and brook trout spawning areas. suitably located cobble shoals for lake trout and nearshore areas for brook trout - areas of potential groundwater upwellings.

Not sure how images / video differs from habitat but I can‰Ûªt envision an AUV collecting question driven imagery without user intervention.Water samples would be nice but equipping AUV with a good multi-sonde / LOPC could likely get most info (because AUV would be payload limited to a finite number of samples)
Substrate composition, Depth
Material and structure make up (i.e., rocky, sand, woody debris).
Substrate features including biota
Lentic area larval sea lamprey habitat
Spawning habitat, nursery habitat, substrate type, depth, flow, temperature, DO
Mapping of substrate types and bathymetry as well as macrophyte beds would be most useful.

Mapping of habitat characteristics is critical to identifying available spawning habitat for Great Lakes fishes, particularly for native species restoration where habitat for various life stages may be lacking.

For Sonar detections do you meant hydro-acoustic surveys or acoustic telemetry? I am assuming hydro-acoustic survey in my answer . The how oftern does not make sense - (a survey once per year which could be every day or one day a year?

habitat can be many things, temp, oxygen, light/ darkness, plants, rocks, substrate type, high res data on these parameters is rare.generally speaking i would be most interested in substrate type and associated plant growth vs rock size, sand, silt
Lake trout, Walleye, and Sturgeon for suitability and quality

We would love to be able to georeference our habitats - specifically a barrier put in place to prevent invasives from colonizing an area.  Using an AUV would also be useful to map out our trap lines when they are in the water
Substrate, mussel cover, submerged aquatic vegetation
Having an up to date map of nearshore habitat would be useful during the review of shoreline development proposals.
Map out coarse substrates for spawning, and potentially capture fish using those habitats.
Critical spawning habitats

I don't know enough about the sonar technology to understand if it could be useful.  Part of the uncertainty is related to technology, but another part is related to scale.  I don't have enough information about water samples to know whether they make sense either.

I don't know enough about the sonar technology to understand if it could be useful.  Part of the uncertainty is related to technology, but another part is related to scale.  I don't have enough information about water samples to know whether they make sense either.

Mapping habitat may be useful for determining areas with a high probability of reproductive success or likely nursery areas. It may also be useful in determining areas that need to be restored on the Great Lakes.

Mapping bottom substrate types would be very useful for investigating current spawning areas, and what little mapping has been done was often pre-dreissinid invasion and those substrates may have been altered

Only coarse maps of bottom substrate types are available in only a few parts of Lake Michigan, and those are outdated and likely have changed. Mapping of large woody debris complexes would be useful as well.
Thermal cover, spawning locations, wetted areas
Mapping Great Lakes tributary habitats would give managers the ability to determine which habitats should be protected and which could benefit from restoration.
Lamprey spawning habitat in tributariesQuagga/Zebra mussel aggregations
Detailed maps of bottom habitat as a GIS layer upon which layers of other data could be added
Depth contours, substrate, vegetation cover and height, amount of woody debris, etc.
Substrate hardness/roughness, vegetation, etc.

There is a lot to learn about habitat throughout Lake Michigan - bottom substrate, habitat/structure in the open water vs. nearshore, etc.  We are routinely asked to review permit applications for dredging projects or habitat improvement projects without a strong knowledge of what the existing habitat is like.
Mapping can be done once every 2-5 years
Sediment structure, vegetation.
Depth, substrate, plant cover would all be useful measurements for me.
I believe AUVs could be used to identify offshore habitat (e.g., reefs) and nearshore habitat (e.g., cobble/boulder fields and submerged vegetation.

Data characterizing substrate are not consistently available for many areas of the lakes, including nearshore regions and tributary mouths, at a resolution that can help us to understand differences in productivity that could result from differences in substrate.  Additionally, we lack data on other types of habitat structures that may exist in areas of the lakes.

It would be beneficial to map spawning habitat where aggregations of spawning Cisco are found.  On Lake Superior, we have declining frequency and amplitude of Cisco recruitment events over the past 40 years. A better understanding of spawning habitat and behavior could assist in identifying causes of recruitment failure.

QID27 - 9. If you chose images/video, what specifically do you think would be most important to capture in images/video?
9. If you chose images/video, what specifically do you think would be most important to capture in images/video?

Lamprey attachment occurrence information would be helpful to me, along with behavioral images from spawning aggregations and other times of the season.  Where in the water column do we see different types of fish during the year.   Always on the bottom, always suspended, both?
Evidence of spawning behavior or egg deposition
Fish movement; feeding; spawning; types of substrates and colonization by any invasive species.
The bottom
We have started to consider using video and images to index adult walleye abundance during the spawn.

As noted above, images and video can be very informative (we collect many hours of footage every year) but they are generally designed around specific questions that require user intervention (stop, slow, zoom, pan, rotate, etc) that I can‰Ûªt see happening in a super valuable way with an AUV on a programmed course (constant speed and course). Also within habitats characterization, in a general way in guess I figured there would be some recording of basic features (likely with video). What other attributes would be considered: bathymetry, substrate classification (size, hardness, poreosity, mussels / epibenthos, macrophyte density & height (and type), etc
Any video work needs to be highly targeted. Thousands of hours of underwater footage is very boring.
Group size, species identification, and behaviors (space use during migratory movements).
spawning, feeding, schooling behavior
Algal cover of substrate
Observations of specific habitat types selected for spawning and behaviours of spawning fish.
Spawning activity for native fish species, specifically lake trout, lake sturgeon, and lake whitefish.
Targeted images of suspected spawning habitat
Fish use of spawning grounds - any other sorts of behavioral aspects to spawning (eg inter- and intraspecific interactions among fish during spawning)
# of invasive species like gobies or lamprey
Use of spawning substrate; to determine the importance of substrate quality ,fouling for egg development & hatching.  Also to observe predation on eggs, larvae.
evidence for use
The use of the habitat by aquatic invasive species - if we could, it would be ideal to even inspect the predation of eggs occurring by aquatic invasives.
any and all videos of fish in the environment are very popular with the public, and are useful during outreach activities.
Images of habitat conditions
Bottom substrate, clodophora and dreissenid mussel colonization of rocky susbtrate.  Blue-green algal blooms
Round goby and dreissenid mussel densities, bottom substrate type
Bottom substrate and fish or inverts using the area.
fish behaviour at/near spawning locations
Habitat features. Spawning fish. Feeding fish. Invasive species (extent and type).
Benthic community composition, video of sufficient quality for identification of pelagic and benthic fish
Bottom habitat and inverts
Physical habitat and fishes

If the swarm has the ability to travel with fish, it would be highly informative to have images of sea lamprey attacks/attachments, especially first attacks of recently metamorphosed sea lampreys as they exit the streams and enter the lake.

Recreational anglers regularly report seeing large "bait balls" on their graphs.  Their assumption is that the bait balls are schools of alewives.  It would be nice to get footage that would either confirm or deny their suspicions.
Impacts to spawning grounds- predation, disturbance etc...
substrate measurements (sonar and hardness measures) need some images to validate and type.
Type/location of spawning fish. Specific habitat use by non-spawning fish.
Trying to determine whether correlation between HAB characteristics and visual appearance
presence or absence, instances of feeding or predation, spawning.
It seems like there is not a lot known about the specific interactions and behaviors of deep water fish in the Great Lakes. Videos would be very helpful at these harder to observe depths.
Round Goby abundances, habitat features, nesting fish.

Identified habitat may be able to be monitored for use as spawning/nursery areas and presence of invasive species (e.g., Dreissenid mussels and Rond Goby).  Video imaging would be useful in this process and could also be used to locate or identify juvenile life stages of certain species (e,g., Lake Trout and Lake Whitefish).
Related to collection of habitat data, I think that image/video of substrate conditions or other structures would be helpful.
nearshore and tributary habitat characteristics, fish assembleges
